Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2012 04:22AM mebmarj wrote: Ports are wonderful!!! Easy to access, get labs drawn off them. The nurses do have to be specially trained to access them, lab personnel usually can not access them without special training either. Oh, if you forget to ask for EMLA or numbing cream, they usually have lidocaine available. Yes, it is a little shot, goes just below the skin with a small needle. Not bad at all.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo July 2012 teeballmom SusanHG123

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2012 10:07PM mebmarj wrote: A year ago I'd just had my second round of taxotere and carboplatin. Not fun stuff, but I did 6 rounds, finished up the end of September. My hair has come back, thicker than before, go figure! I feel pretty good and am doing reconstruction. Some things to have on hand, just in case... Anti diarrhea meds. Constipation meds. Wet wipes. Nausea meds. Maalox or mylanta for heartburn. Comfort foods that are bland. Drinks that are nonacidic to keep hydrated. Chemo regimens are different and so are people, so of course ask your doc their advice on what you need and can take based on your situation. Best wishes to you!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo July 2012 teeballmom SusanHG123

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2011 02:02AM mebmarj wrote: Get another opinion, a copy of the report and definitely include the family history when speaking with someone. 3cm is nothing to sneeze at or wait upon. I was dx at 32 and told I was too young. Another new primary dx at 39. No family hx, non smoker, not obese, active, eat well... And still won the BC lottery, twice. Please, please, please keep on this and trust your gut. Best wishes to you.
Posts.Title: Anyone told they're too young? jamjam29 kennessee

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2012 06:42AM mebmarj wrote: Biotene works pretty well and freshens a little with no pain from alcohol like in others. Magic mouthwash from onc's office works great.  I'm sure they can call it to your pharmacy. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Mouth sores silentbell shaah2468

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2012 09:10PM mebmarj wrote: Waiting on a word from the dr office stinks. However here are a few things to ponder. You didn't mention your age but this is your first mammogram. So in essence there is nothing to compare this one to, right? The extra views may be for a baseline for you since there is some family history. Also, the younger you are- the more dense breast tissue is and extra views are kind of good thing, it means they're looking and taking time with your films. Even though there is some family history there, not everyone has the genes. They still don't know for sure how some of us get it and others don't. Definitely take charge and get the follow up done for your piece of mind. You'll have answers soon. Take care and best wishes to you.
Posts.Title: Worried to death!!! Pinkpearl39 Pinkpearl39

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2018 03:38PM mebmarj wrote: invasive carcinoma is listed and they list lobular neoplasia- which is the type of cancer. A stereotactic biopsy is looking for calcifications which they also identified. Calcifications become a concern on a mammogram when they increase in number/size and have different shapes(not looking all the same). A full pathology report they will have a list of hormone receptor status among other things. I would encourage you to help her get a consult with her doctor and a surgeon to discuss the report more in depth. You have some really good questions so write them down (and others you may have) and take them asking to help your mom get the information she needs to move forward with treatment and surgical choices.
Posts.Title: Need help understanding biopsy carmen24 Moderators

Posts.Content: May 16, 2013 07:20PM mebmarj wrote: It must have been a very thoughtful process from decision to the op-Ed piece earlier this week. So often the media takes a celebrity story and runs with it, spinning it, cutting out details here and there, scaring people and throwing little factoids around that can have devastating effects on the person and our society in general. By getting in front of the release of information, AJ not only took control of her situation again but also the public perception of it. It wasnt leaked or twisted, it was just the facts as they occurred to her. Some people may not agree with her rationale, her surgery, her words used in the piece, the fact that she can afford whatever care she needs or wants, had recon and didn't reveal the horrors of what can possibly happen because they didn't happen to her, whatever. You can't please everyone all the time. Its impossible. There will always be criticisms, opinions, and discussion of celebrity health news. The fact that she could get in front of a diagnosis and possibly avoid one, that probably pisses off a lot of people who didn't or couldn't, and didn't have risk factors other than having boobs. Life isn't fair. Cancer sucks. Pink ribbons suck too because they have been bastardized and now give so many people the wrong impression. It's good she has been able to ignite a fire in people who are passionate and start some discussion for others who need to be more informed. You have to admit, the piece has people talking, asking questions and encourages us to be better self-health advocates.
Posts.Title: Angelina Jolie's prophylactic surgery JoanQuilts SusansGarden

Posts.Content: May 14, 2013 10:06AM mebmarj wrote: Wow, that was a fantastic article. People on these boards have not been very kind on another thread and it really floors me. For all we know AJ may be on here with us, looking for support, helping others and bitching just like the rest of us about how scary the cancer experience is. While she may not have had the dx, she is the daughter of someone who passed from cancer. That sucks, it's frightening and any one of us that could do what she did probably would have jumped at the chance to avoid the road we were forced to travel. AJ- If you are with us here on BCO, sorry for your loss, glad you have support and thank you for your willingness to share. As to the tiny scars remark some people have taken offense to- who wouldn't try to minimize the impact on their children? How many of us have glossed over the gory surgical or treatment details in mixed company? How many of us don't want to talk about breast cancer all the time? When she is ready, I'm sure she'll say or do more. No one of us is perfect, it's easy to be critical and pass judgement, but how often have we all bitched about people's comments and stupidity in the face of our personal challenges related to breast cancer? Cut the woman some slack. Good luck to you AJ.
Posts.Title: Angelina Jolie's prophylactic surgery JoanQuilts SusansGarden

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2011 12:51PM mebmarj wrote: I had lumpectomy and treatment with chemo and rads back in 2004.  People who found out about my BC would ask, sometimes while looking at my chest, did they remove your breast? Ugh, yes, I know they wonder and are concerned but really? So now I'll get to tell them, yes, both cause they tried to kill me twice!
Posts.Title: How do you answer "did they catch it early?" oaktownmom 208sandy

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2011 12:52PM mebmarj wrote: Anytime someone asks a question that seems intrusive, reply with "what do you mean?" They may realize how rude their question was by just trying to explain it to you...
Posts.Title: How do you answer "did they catch it early?" oaktownmom 208sandy

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2012 08:19AM mebmarj wrote: Had my BMX 10 months ago. Opted for delayed recon due to chemo. The layered look is the way I camouflage what's going on there. I have found some pretty nice cami tops in the juniors section at JC Penney (spaghetti straps) and some that are a cotton/poly blend tank or long sleeve tee at old navy. Comfy and feel like support without being restrictive. Lots of colors too to put under button down tops, vests or sweaters. Now that I don't have the do-rags, decorative neck scarves have been added too. Yeah, all the hoopla was helpful at first but they don't understand we don't just "get over it" that easy. It's a loss. You're allowed to feel anything you want to- cause we've all been there or still are there with you. Best wishes to you :)
Posts.Title: processing what just happened lynliz mebmarj

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2014 08:19AM - edited Apr 30, 2014 11:04AM by mebmarj There is no "right" way to deal with breast concerns.  Trust your gut, do your follow ups for imaging and clinical exams, get a second or third opinion if needed.   The are so many people on the boards: diagnosed, going through treatment, those with questions, concerns and family history, as well as caregivers and family members.  No matter what our status, we are all allowed to feel what we feel.  Information overload can worsen it, yes.  But being an informed health consumer is very important.  If you know worst case scenario- anything else is better right? Counseling, medications and support groups are available too.  Please use caution when thinking about a prophy mast. It is major surgery to reduce risk, alters your physical appearance, self image, as well as mobility.  Reconstruction is a complex process.  If you are really serious, talk to several surgeons about the entire process before you commit.   Best of luck to you. FYI- twice diagnosed BC here, in my 30s both times.  There were days, weeks even, when it didn't take center stage in my day. Please talk to your dr about your anxiety.
Posts.Title: How do you deal with the anxiety? alicki sarahjane7374

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2012 02:33AM mebmarj wrote: Purse became lighter. No brush/comb to carry around for myself. No pads/tampons needed. So when people (DD) asks if I had a brush or pads, I just looked at her and said, "No, why?!"
Posts.Title: So, you won the chemo lottery? TRY to find the humor! PlantLover fredntan

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2012 01:40AM mebmarj wrote: With the initial tumor and sentinel nodes you get stage and grade. Yes stage II is appearance of cancer cells in the lymph nodes. Grade is how aggressive the cancer cells appear to be under a microscope. Diagnosis can be changed with further scans. There are a number of tests to determine the course of treatment, many of which you can read about through the home and information pages of breast cancer.org and other places. Advise her to get someone to go with her to the appts to help remember info, write questions down before going and don't be afraid to ask questions. This is a whole new language to get to know. Please be patient with her. You admit to anger and frustration, she has that plus so much more going on in her head. Others will come along and try to help you here too. You might tell her this site was suggested as a great resource and let her explore in her own time. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: SOOO many questions benture25 dragonfly1

Posts.Content: mebmarj wrote: I haven't posted in while but am in need of others that may have the knowledge I seek. Original dx in dec 03 was IDC, officially stage 1. At the time of SNB, the IMC nodes lit up first. The two axillary nodes taken were both negative. Lumpectomy with reexcision done, 6 rounds chemotherapy (CE&5Fu), then 33 rads. Follow up every 6 months for 7 years. Last fall it was decided to go yearly. Two weeks ago today I found a grape sized lump just centimeters away from the original site. It was mammo'd, US and then removed. It is another cancer. Full path not yet back. Tentatively, mastectomy of the involved side with chemotherapy after that. Don't know what to think of reconstruction. Any thoughts or advice on how to proceed are appreciated. Blessings to you and yours -m Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: New primary? 7 years later here we go, again. mebmarj AnneW

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2012 10:59AM mebmarj wrote: Unfortunately when a person sees the same type of situation in numerous repeated caes, it can make them jaded. Why bother to try to heal the world if they can't do the work to maintain the machine? Yes, there are diseases and addictions. But when some people become so ill, their world becomes smaller and smaller over time until all there is, is the illness. They can't see beyond their pain or need for a substance. The dr seems judgmental because they know without that substance the patient would have a better chance at life, but the patient can't, won't or plain old doesn't want to give up the habits. It's a vicious cycle, and to some degree we all fall into it. Maybe that's why it seems so offensive. It also seems unfair that while some of us live a good life on the whole and get the cancer curse, other people seem to throw life away willy nilly. Someone who wants to save lives, constantly seeing their efforts just unappreciated could get a little sad don't you think?
Posts.Title: Doctors who think they are God CoolBreeze CoolBreeze

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2011 03:45PM mebmarj wrote: Ask what your platelet count is. Platelets being low would also be cause for a bleed after blowing the nose, broken vessels can't clot without adequate platelets!

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2012 12:47AM - edited Jun 29, 2012 12:47AM by mebmarj Had right sided IDC, lumpectomy, chemo and rads in 2004. In 2010 had unusual patch of skin on left side. Hmmm. Itchy. Red. Irritated. Showed my onc. Sent for MRI. An area of uptake of the contrast. Not my first concern, but an additional one. Hmmm. Sent for US guided bx. Dr had a tech deliver the path report, no problems found. So about the itchy red area?! My surgeon zipped it off. Sent it to pathology. No problem there either. Best wishes to you.
Posts.Title: Scares anyone can share that turned out to be nothing? fondak fondak

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2008 09:25AM mebmarj wrote: Shelby, One of the best things you can do is make a list of your questions and concerns for your doctors.  It gives you a little reminder of certain things that may or may not get addressed during an appt, and an opportunity to get some ideas to your questions. I was 32 at diagnosis.  Also right breast.  Scared with all the waiting, but came here often.  Did chemo(ask about a port) and rads.  I haven't visited the site in a while, but I'm glad I came today to meet you.  The people here all have their own stories and unique situations and yours will be your own too.  Knowledge is power.  Learn what you need to know to make the best decisions for you and your situation. -M
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed Thursday thedudess janet11

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2011 12:24AM - edited Apr 3, 2011 12:26AM by mebmarj @Sheribell- Seeing this is my second go round, yeah I've been playing the guessing game. How? If this, then that... It doesn't make any sense at all. Nonsmoker. Took the pill. Worked in radio with transmitters around our station. Possible DES exposure in utero. I eat well, not too much exercise but not obese either. Then there are all the lovely reports the media like to bring out every so often, "too much this or that increases risk of blah, blah, blah..." My answer, I'm just that freaking lucky and I should be playing the lottery! Fatigue is easy to set in here too. Slept in bed with pillows last night and felt like I got beat up all day today. Back to the corner of the couch in my cocoon tonight. @Janet- glad I did prophy too. Path came back with no issues, but brca hadn't gotten back yet. Got brca results and I'm negative. So once again, time to play the lottery?! I feel like I'm doing mostly well. Not really up to talking with anybody that doesn't already know what's going on. Physically the range of motion is decent, no axillary dissection was needed as biopsy gave clear margins. But sore, real sore at times and it's so frustrating not doing all the things I'm accustomed to doing myself. And wardrobe issues... Need some new stuff. No TEs for quite some time- they're thinking well after I finish chemo- and not thinking I'm going to do the prostheses either. Need some light collared tops and scarves I think. Any suggestions? Take care -M

More comfortable without the drains, but also tender. Will be 2 weeks out on Wednesday. Resting/sleeping still kind of an issue. Wake up sore if I get too low in the cocoon at the end of the couch. Take care.

Hope surgery goes well for you. Keep up the good work, keep your hands busy and know you are strong enough to do it!

Spent one night in the hospital and discharged home after dinner the next day. Drains were pulled on Mon 3/28. Doing pretty well. Considering doing recon after treatment is all done. Had pet scan that showed hot right ovary, then ultrasound results showed enlarged uterus and ovary. I've been advised to have a hyst. My brca was neg. Looks like hyst at the end of April then heal up and go onto chemo. Take care -M

Posts.Title: Is this being over-sensitive? Outfield Kicks

Posts.Content: May 13, 2011 12:40AM - edited May 13, 2011 12:41AM by mebmarj kks_rd- There is a pretty long and darn funny thread about people's suggestions how to "cure" BC. It's pretty sarcastic and not at serious, but good for the funny bone. It's called "OMG they found the cure for stupid." People generally intend to help, but don't really have a clue what we go through.with treatment. mlabroli- Sorry to hear about you too. This is my second time with BC. First time I was 32 and the kids were 4/9 yrs old. Had lumpectomy, chemotherapy and rads back then. Did everything right. This one popped up after 7 years of follow up. Kids are now 11/16 yrs old. It was hard the first time but the hair grows back and not everyone has recurrence or a new primary tumor happen. First time I was ER- and this time I'm ER+. I'm 7 wks post mastectomy with prophylactic mast on the good side. Had toyed with idea of a hyst due for a while(painful periods), well the PET scan helped suggest to get it done. I am now 3 weeks post hyst with ovary removal. Both of you can do this. You'll find you are capable of many things, especially when it comes to saving your life and making plans to live it fully in the future. Work of one kind or another will always be there. It's most important to care for yourselves today. May sound a bit selfish, but you can't do squat to help others if you don't care for yourself first. Remember you CAN accomplish anything you set your mind to doing. Wishing you both well with your coming decisions and treatments. -m
Posts.Title: Feels like a bad dream... kks_rd kks_rd

Posts.Title: Embarrasing question- but need to ask. GmaFoley barbe1958

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2011 09:46PM - edited Jul 11, 2011 09:47PM by mebmarj Have you ladies getting ready for rads had your sim yet? Like 38yo said, you'll probably get little tattoos (tiny actually), after some CTs,etc. They may make sharpie marker lines too, to indicate fields to treat. It takes a little while for the team to work it all up. That was all 7 years ago I did that, you will do fine. Ask questions if you have them. Often it takes longer for you to change clothes and get positioned by the techs than it does for the actual treatment. Best of luck to y'all with upcoming "cocktail hours" and "extreme tanning." :) -m
Posts.Title: Chemo May 2011 Cyborg

Posts.Content: May 15, 2011 10:32PM mebmarj wrote: Hi May Ladies, I'll be in the June group, but wanted to give you some info. Neupogen came first and then neulasta. Like someone said previous, the neulasta is one shot that lasts longer. They used to have a commercial that stated to expect mild to moderate bone pain. It was more then moderate for me. Did this stuff seven years ago. The whole idea behind the two shots is to encourage your long/major bone marrow areas to kick it up and improve your white counts. That's where the bone pain comes in the femur, hip carriage, spine and sternum. The chemo attacks fast growing cells, the blood cells are fast along with the hair follicles and the GI tract. As far as constipation, prune juice with a splash of lemon or try eating some raisin bran. Wishing you all well, -m
Posts.Title: Chemo May 2011 Cyborg

Posts.Content: May 1, 2011 11:42PM mebmarj wrote: This site has been so helpful, I'm glad you logged in. It sucks to get the diagnosis and be in between knowing what is going to be done about it. The threads are a good way to learn and know best case or worst case scenario, because everyone is different. Dr Susan Love's Breast Book is a really good read and available electronically too. You'll find you'll have to tell people about this and there will be different reactions. Some really and truly care, but they are afraid for you and them because they don't like it when bad stuff happens to people they know and love. Some really and truly care, will be there no matter what whenever YOU call because they want to help but not intrude. You'll also encounter those who might ask questions and make comments that normally might not bother you, but suddenly it hits you the wrong way. Others simply filter out because they can't deal with it, not YOU, but it- the cancer. Just remember to take it day by day. It's ok to cry, be mad, be anxious- it's all normal for us here. Make your calls tomorrow and your plan will be getting started. Please let us know how you are doing. Wishing you well. -m
Posts.Title: Feels like a bad dream... kks_rd kks_rd

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2011 07:53AM mebmarj wrote: Kat Call the onc's office. If it's from chemo, they've probably seen and treated it before. I had some weird dry, red, scaly areas on my chin and face. Was given medrol dose pack that helped. Give them a call and get some relief. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Chemo May 2011 Cyborg

Posts.Content: May 27, 2011 09:16PM mebmarj wrote: Restricting fresh stuff depends on if you are neutropenic. Chances are if you are being given neupogen or neulasta, you've had low counts in the past they are trying to prevent from occurring with each of your cycles. If you are going to have fresh stuff it does have to be thoroughly cooked. Also leftovers are supposed to be thoroughly heated to a boiling point. Possible to do with soups, plain pasta and some sauces on the stovetop, but can't exactly predict the microwave cooking. Your best bet is call the onc's office for clarification. Best wishes to you all. -m
Posts.Title: Chemo May 2011 Cyborg

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2011 12:14AM mebmarj wrote: There is no right or wrong choice as far as lumpectomy or mastectomy. It's what you feel you need to do for yourself. At 32 yo I had IDC 1.8 cm that was triple negative with lumpectomy, reexcision with snb, FEC times 6, and 33 rads. All clinically the right things to do for that dx. I did NOT have a recurrence, but a brand spanking new cancer that was ER+, after 7 years of knowing NED. So, I went with the mastectomy, waiting on reconstruction til after finishing chemo. Do I wish I'd had a mastectomy to start? No. There was a very good chance I would not have cancer again. I was tested a few months ago and do not have the brca1 or 2, and there is NO family history for me. I was the first on my family. I'll never understand why I got another dance with the beast. I only know that by taking it for team twice, sixteen people I know statistically shouldn't get it in their lifetime... All any of us can do is process the info we have at the time, listen to what options the dr offers and go with the one that is right for you. None of it is an easy decision and others that haven't been there- they just can't understand how much it takes to do all this tx. Thanks to you May gals for your advice and sharing your experiences. It helped with my new start of chemo at the beginning of June. Wishing you all the best. -m
Posts.Title: Chemo May 2011 Cyborg

Posts.Content: May 16, 2011 10:19AM mebmarj wrote: In reference to the two shots- I was referring to the neulasta and the neupogen. Neulasta is a single shot usually given day or so after chemo to prevent low WBC and neutropenia. Neupogen, the other type given, is a series of daily shots. In my first round a few years back, they weren't sure what my counts would do. When I had blood work about a week to ten days after, sure enough I was way low. That got me the neupogen shots for a few days in a row. After that they decided to prevent the low counts and gave the neulasta day after chemo. Hope I clarified that, sorry for the confusion. Yep, the procrit reaction is similar. More pain in my femurs with that one, whereas the neupogen and neulasta were all over bone pain. I think chemo is the way to go. It sucks, but there are so many other factors to consider. Wanting to zap any stray cells, that's the way to go. Best wishes everyone.
Posts.Title: Chemo May 2011 Cyborg

Posts.Content: May 9, 2011 06:21PM mebmarj wrote: Well you are moving right along! I agree the MRI position is soooo uncomfortable. I had a hard time breathing after a few minutes with the way they positioned my neck and head at first. But then they paused to do contrast and adjusted my head :) Glad the dr is working well with you and you are getting support. I go to see my onc tomorrow. Again, wishing you well with your treatment & take care.
Posts.Title: Feels like a bad dream... kks_rd kks_rd
